author: Jonathon Manning
title: SCS narrows losses but warns of 'challenging' start to second half of 2017
text:
SCS narrows losses but warns of 'challenging' start to second half of 2017 The Sunderland-based sofa company reduced its losses to £2.6m at the half-year mark Share David Knight, chief executive of ScS Share Get business   
Sunderland furniture specialist ScS has narrowed its first-half losses to £2.6m as it saw a rise in turnover and expanded into new areas. 
The loss before tax of £2.6m, for the six months ending January 28 2017, was a slight improvement on the same period last year when the firm made a loss of £3.4m. 
Despite continuing to be in the red, ScS managed to grow turnover by 14.6%, from £137.7m to £157.9m. 
CEO David Knight said that after the interim period the firm had suffered from a “challenging February” but he remained upbeat due to the upcoming bank holidays. 
Speaking in the interim results Mr Knight said: “Trading in February was challenging, largely driven by reduced footfall. However, we have seen an improvement since the start of March. 
“We remain mindful that the group still faces the key Easter and May bank holiday trading periods and faces very strong comparatives during the remainder of the year. The board believes the business remains in a strong position to maximise opportunities as they arise and to grow market share. 
“Given the year to date performance of the business, the board currently expects results for the financial year to be in line with expectations.” 
ScS increased its interim dividend to 4.9p, up from 4.67p the year before. Read More Housebuilder Bellway sees profits rise 9% as buyers shrug off Brexit uncertainty 
During the six months ending 28 January 2017 the firm opened four new stores in Aberdeen, Thanet, Straiton, and Plymouth. The company now trades from 100 ScS stores and operates 28 House of Fraser concessions. 
The firm’s concession business brought in £12.8m, up 22.9% from £10.4m in 2016. Online sales also increased with gross sales from ScS’s e-commerce platform growing 25%, from £4.3m to £5.4m. 
ScS describes itself as a seasonal business and the loss it makes in the first half of the year is not unusually for the firm. Read More Small businesses reveal Brexit wish list as Government moves to trigger Article 50 
In the 2015/16 financial year, 43% of ScS’s turnover was made in the first half of the year and it made an operating loss of £3.4m. In the second half of the year, the firm brought in 57% of its total revenue and it made an operating profit of £14.4m. Like us on Facebook
